sentence.text: Patient 2 is the second child born to a non-consanguineous 23-year-old-mother and 29-year-old father of Northern European heritage who is no longer involved in the relationship.
Prenatal ultrasound studies of patient two detected hydrops and polyhydramnios, but no fetal structural abnormalities.
The child was delivered at 39 weeks of gestation by repeat C-section with Apgar scores of 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 min, respectively.
The birth weight was 3,600 g and length 52 cm (both 90th centile), although the OFC was 32.5 cm (10th centile).

A syndrome was suggested by the “cloverleaf” small cranium, bitemporal narrowness, tall forehead, and posteriorly displaced anterior fontanel (approximately 2 cm × 2 cm) with slightly low set ears, markedly upslanted palpebral fissures, large palpebral fissures (inner canthal distance ∼2.5 cm and outer canthal distance ∼7.5 cm, both more than 2 SD for age), flat nasal bridge, upturned nares, and epicanthal folds.
The philtrum was long and smooth with a somewhat thin vermilion of the upper lip, and chin was small.
Scalp hair, brows, and lashes were sparse.
The neck skin was redundant, and fingers were short and broad, limbs were short (Fig. 2).
Treatment included a gastrostomy button, a ventriculoperitoneal shunt at age 2.5 months followed by a revision, and a craniectomy to release multisutural craniosynostoses at 4.5 months.
At 4 months, he was hypotonic with global developmental delays, and was being treated for seizures.
His head shape remained severely oxycephalic and the left pinna was small, thin and prominent (Fig. 2a,b).
Results of auditory brainstem response testing were normal.
Imaging included a CT scan of the head which showed multiple suture synostoses with closure of the metopic, left coronal and sagittal suture, and partial closure of the left lambdoid suture.
MRI scan noted slight dilation of ventricles, more prominent in the frontal horns and a large draining scalp vein in the right occipital region.
We were not able to perform studies of cilia in the tissue and cells of either patient as this material was unavailable to us.
